snippet: The Associated Press reported that the Justice Department had secretly obtained the phone records of its offices and journalists, calling it a “massive and unprecedented intrusion.”
abstract: Federal investigators secretly seize two months of phone records for reporters and editors of The Associated Press in what the news organization calls 'massive and unprecedented intrusion'; AP says Justice Dept informed it that law enforcement officials have obtained records for more than 20 telephone lines of its offices and journalists, including home phones and cellphones, and says records were seized without notice or explanation.

byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and LESLIE KAUFMAN
byline.contributor: Charlie Savage reported from Washington, and Leslie Kaufman from New York. Christine Haughney contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: The Associated Press reported that the Justice Department had secretly obtained the phone records of its offices and journalists, calling it a “massive and unprecedented intrusion.”

headline.seo: Phone Records of Journalists of The Associated Press Seized by U.S.
headline.main: Phone Records of Journalists Seized by U.S.
headline.print_headline: Phone Records Of Journalists Seized by U.S.
